text: so my name is Jed son wall and I run the open data program at AWS and one of the
first things I like to get out of the way when talking about the open data program is answer why we have an open
data program and the the short answer to this question is is that open data is really important to a lot of our
customers we have in the public sector as you may have heard we have tens of thousands of customers around the world
and many of these customers are required by law or by their mission to share data
to make data open and available and then on the other side of this we have you
know we have millions of customers all over the world and many of them rely on access to data to build their products
and services you know they might provide some sort of data product or some sort of software application that analyzes
and makes sense of open data that governments have shared and the cloud has a lot to offer when it comes to not
only providing all the storage infrastructure to host that data and make it available but also to analyze it
on the other end and what we do in our program and and what our what our
mission is is to expand access to data that's the main thing is that what we try to do is make create a world in
which more people have access to data every day you know we're trying to make sure that people who didn't have access
to data yesterday might have better access to that data today and the way that we do that is by finding ways to
stage data for analysis in the cloud and if you go to our site we've got a nice site I mean I think it's a nice site
open data AWS you can see some examples of what our customers are doing today to
make data easier to access by making it available in the cloud one of the ways
that we do this do our work is through the public data set program it's called AWS public data set program and in this
program we actually collaborate with a lot of our customers to find to figure
out new ways to stage data for analysis in the cloud and now it's probably a good chance for me to explain like what
why I keep using this very specific phrase stage data for analysis in the cloud it's very easy to look at AWS or
the cloud and if you're familiar with Amazon s3 our storage service and think of it a lot like it like an
FTP server it's like wow it's like a the best FTP server I could ever imagine that is true you know it is it does act
a lot like an FTP server but the real value of making data available in the cloud is that it allows you to work with
the data and an s3 in particular has a provides a lot of affordances for you to work with data without moving it around
very much so that you can very precisely query or interrogate data in massive
amounts of data without moving it around and this has a huge impact on on
research in terms of saving time you know and cost savings because it means
that people can work with with large volumes of data without having to to download or copy
you know those volumes of data and so what we do is we try to we work with
these these customers who have large and interesting datasets and we try to figure out what is the best way to stage
this data for analysis in the cloud and that's basically the thrust of what we're gonna talk about today and when my
colleague Dave Rocco Moore comes up he's going to talk in much more detail about what we've learned from doing this you

all the time you know I'm seeing heads not here the the really great thing about this book that was they wrote it

problem in many cases and especially these days data scientists are in demand
there aren't that many of them there's a very competitive market for them so you probably pay them a good amount of money
you don't want them spending most of their time just preparing data for analysis or just downloading data now
you want to get them to get to work on the analysis and and do what they're good at and and it's it can be very
frustrating I guess is what I'll say is we've worked with a lot of researchers and we've talked to a lot of our customers who they've wanted access or
they've had ideas of cool things they could do with data sets just getting the data is blocking them
they either don't have the storage capacity themselves they can't afford it themselves if they went and asked IT for

hear this all the time and we hear this from a lot of I mean from customers that even have you know a fair amount of

questions and we have a term for this at 88 oh yeah sorry actually the Amazon we
use this author ed Amazon this idea of undifferentiated heavy lifting undifferentiated heavy lifting as all
the work that you or your team has to do that is keeping them from doing or keeping you from doing what you actually
want to do you know from what your actual mission is or what you're actually good at and everything that we
do at AWS is designed to attack undifferentiated heavy lifting we're always trying to you know work with our
customers listen to them find out what it is that they have to do that's keeping them from doing what they're

allows researchers to cut to eliminate a lot of undifferentiated heavy lifting

all 12 of the images and a bunch of other you know kind of data in there and it's all packed up and for a customer to

and then we reorder the bytes inside of the image into a format called cloud
optimized geo TIFF and that does the thing called internal tiling which long story short it allows you to select I
